title: [FEATURE] Replace <PackageLicenseUrl> with <PackageLicenseExpression>
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem?

We are currently adapting a package approval workflow, where packages are approved or blocked based on certain criteria. One very important criterion is the package's license. There is a list of approved licenses (like MIT, Apache, ...) and a list of licenses that cannot be used (like GPL).

Although your package seems to be under MIT license, it's hard to auto-approve this package, because it uses a license URL (which is a [deprecated mechanism](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec#licenseurl)) instead of an SPDX tag (https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2-draft/SPDX-license-list/). As a result, the license does not show up in the package's metadata (compare e.g. the "About" section of https://www.nuget.org/packages/SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies with https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Data.SqlClient, where the latter clearly states the package's license, while your package does not).


### Describe the solution you would like

Would you consider using an SPDX license expression? Basically, all that is needed is replacing the line
`<PackageLicenseUrl>https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=868514</PackageLicenseUrl>` (or whatever URL is used)
with
`<PackageLicenseExpression>MIT</PackageLicenseExpression>`
in all *.csproj or *.props files (or whatever mechanism generates the corresponding *.nuspec file). An additional LICENSE file can still remain in the package, just the metadata would change. The corresponding .nuspec file should then change the line
`<licenseUrl>https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=868514</licenseUrl>`
to
`<license type="expression">MIT</license>`


### Describe alternatives you have considered

The alternative would be for us to download every package, manually check the context of each embedded LICENSE file or the license URL, make sure that it is in fact an approved license, and then manually allow the package. This would have to be done for every release of every package without an SPDX license tags.

### Additional context

Using SPDX license identifiers is the recommendation provided in Microsoft's [.nuspec reference](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec#license).
